1Department of Pathology, Radboud University Medical Center, Nijmegen, Netherlands
Center for Medical Image Science and Visualization, Linképing University, Linképing, Sweden
‘e-mail: jeroen.vanderlaak@radboudumc.nl

regions.crop_image_path: /mnt/sh_flex_storage/home/zehanyu/repos/GPT-Paper/pdfs/cancer_review/Deep learning in histopathology the path to the clinics/crops_ordered/page_01/region_4_title.png
/mnt/sh_flex_storage/home/zehanyu/repos/GPT-Paper/pdfs/cancer_review/Deep learning in histopathology the path to the clinics/crops_ordered/page_01/region_5_text.png
regions.text:
Machine learning techniques have great potential to improve medical diagnostics, offering ways to
improve accuracy, reproducibility and speed, and to ease workloads for clinicians. In the field of
histopathology, deep learning algorithms have been developed that perform similarly to trained
pathologists for tasks such as tumor detection and grading. However, despite these promising results,
very few algorithms have reached clinical implementation, challenging the balance between hope and
hype for these new techniques. This review provides an overview of the current state of the field, as
well as describing the challenges that still need to be addressed before artificial intelligence in
histopathology can achieve clinical value.

regions.crop_image_path: /mnt/sh_flex_storage/home/zehanyu/repos/GPT-Paper/pdfs/cancer_review/Deep learning in histopathology the path to the clinics/crops_ordered/page_01/region_6_title.png
/mnt/sh_flex_storage/home/zehanyu/repos/GPT-Paper/pdfs/cancer_review/Deep learning in histopathology the path to the clinics/crops_ordered/page_01/region_7_text.png
regions.text:
Breakthroughs in the field of artificial intelligence (Al) have had a major impact on society worldwide
in the past five years. In the field of medicine, and more specifically in diagnostic disciplines (e.g.,
radiology, pathology), initial results from the application of Al to patient data are very promising [1],
[2], [3]. Diagnostic disciplines often rely heavily on the recognition of patterns in data, such as images,
by physicians and the interpretation of such patterns in the wider context of the patient. However, it
was shown that for many diagnostics tasks, reproducibility among physicians is less than optimal [62],
[73]. Also, as a result of the increase in treatment options, more accurate diagnostics are needed to
meet the requirements of ‘precision medicine’, which may exceed the capabilities of human visual
inspection [154]. Detecting and accurately quantifying patterns in medical data using Al could
therefore aid diagnostic processes, making them more efficient and reproducible, and increasing
accuracy and precision.

regions.crop_image_path: /mnt/sh_flex_storage/home/zehanyu/repos/GPT-Paper/pdfs/cancer_review/Deep learning in histopathology the path to the clinics/crops_ordered/page_01/region_8_text.png
regions.text:
An area in which the use of Al is particularly appealing is in the analysis of histopathological tissue
sections, which currently requires specialized doctors, pathologists, to carefully assess (sometimes
large numbers of) gigapixel-sized images. Pathologists diagnose and grade diseases such as cancer and
